docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Distress More Likely in New York, Study Finds'' (news article, April 10):
docs.abstract: Wendy Brennan letter on data that 41 percent of New York City residents who could benefit from mental health treatment do not seek it because of costs; says barrier would not exist if New York joined 35 other states that require coverage
docs.snippet: To the Editor:      Re ''Distress More Likely in New York, Study Finds'' (news article, April 10):

docs.lead_paragraph: Yield on 10-Year Treasury Note Tops 5%, Signaling Increases for Consumer Debt Costs The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note, which serves as a touchstone for lending rates, rose above 5 percent for the first time in nearly four years, signaling that many borrowers will soon be paying more on mortgages and home equity loans. [Page A1.] Skilling Maintains Innocence Despite Mistakes at Enron Jeffrey K. Skilling admitted in testimony at the Enron fraud trial that he made mistakes, but continued to profess his innocence and blasted the government for charging him with conspiring to defraud Enron investors. [C1.] Repeat of an Auto Bailout Unlikely This Time Just over 25 years ago, Chrysler teetered on the brink of bankruptcy, hobbled by falling sales, heavy payroll costs and bloated debt, and the federal government helped with a bailout. Today General Motors and Ford are in similar positions. But a replay of the federal help is unlikely. [C1.] The Ford Motor Company said it planned to shut its truck plants in St. Paul, Minn., and Norfolk, Va., the latest closings as part of its restructuring program called the Way Forward. Both plants, which are among the oldest at Ford, will shut in 2008, the automaker said. Both opened in 1925 and together employ about 4,300 hourly and salaried workers. [C4.] Pension Accounting Plan Will Cut Corporate Worth A proposal by the Financial Accounting Standards Board to revise the way corporations account for pension obligations would wipe away 8 percent of the nation's corporate wealth, reflecting how poorly current accounting rules reflect a pension fund's need for cash versus a company's ability to provide it, according to a study by an actuarial firm. [C1.] A Chip Maker Turns His Focus to the Sun T.J. Rodgers, who founded Cypress Semiconductor to make high-speed computer memories and the newer specialized chips that go into iPods and high-end Mercedes Benzes, is working on a new kind of chip these days, the kind that soak up the sun's rays to produce electricity. [C1.] Bausch & Lomb to Stop Sales of Suspect Solution After reports of illness and under pressure from major retailers, Bausch & Lomb said it had asked retailers across the nation to temporarily remove its ReNu With MoistureLoc contact lens solution from store shelves. [C3.] TiVo Wins $73 Million in a Patent Lawsuit A federal jury awarded TiVo more than $73 million in damages in a patent infringement lawsuit against EchoStar Communications. [C3.] Retail Sales Better Than Expected in March Retail sales increased 0.6 percent in March, rebounding from a decline of 0.8 percent in February, the Commerce Department said. [C3.] Fidelity Closing Two More Popular Mutual Funds Fidelity Investments said it was closing two large, popular mutual funds to new investors, two weeks after closing its biggest fund, the $65 billion Contrafund. Some analysts interpreted the closings as pre-emptive steps to prevent sagging returns that can result when a fund gets too big. [C5.] Michael Jackson Overhauls His Finances The pop star Michael Jackson, who has been burdened with hundreds of millions of dollars of debt, said he had revamped his finances, an arrangement that would probably force him to sell part of his stake in a song catalog that includes hits by the Beatles. [C2.] General Electric Posts 9% Increase in Profit General Electric said its earnings increased 9 percent in the first quarter and that revenue rose 10 percent as the company benefited from stronger sales of aircraft engines and health equipment. Jeffrey K. Immelt, G.E.'s chief executive, said the company expected a strong year -- orders are up 33 percent overall and 67 percent for equipment. G.E. said it should also be able to sell the last of its slower-growing insurance businesses, GE Life, in the next 12 months. [C3.] Anticipation of Technology Profit Lifts Stocks Stocks rose as anticipation of better-than-expected earnings from technology companies tempered concern about higher interest rates and oil prices. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 7.68 points, to 11,137.65; the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 1 point, to 1,289.12; The Nasdaq composite index advanced 11.43 points, to 2,326.11. [C7.] U.S. Seeks Measures Against a Tax Dodge Promoter The Justice Department is seeking a court order to block a Michigan couple from promoting what the government says is the No. 1 tax scheme in the country and to force them to return more than $20,000 in tax refunds. The government also sued seven people it said used the couple's advice. [C3.]

docs.lead_paragraph: General Electric said yesterday that its earnings increased 9 percent in the first quarter and that revenue rose 10 percent as the company benefited from stronger sales of aircraft engines and health equipment. But the report, which met Wall Street's expectations to the penny, did not excite investors who were hoping the company would raise its earnings forecast for the rest of the year or beat their expectations. Shares closed down 57 cents, or 1.7 percent, to $33.89.

headline.main: G.E. Earnings Increase 9%, Matching Wall St. Forecasts

docs.abstract: General Electric says first-quarter earnings increased 9 percent, to $4.3 billion, compared with $4 billion year earlier; reports revenue rose to $37.8 billion, from $34.4 billion in year-earlier first quarter (M)
docs.snippet: The quarterly report, which met Wall Street's expectations to the penny, did not excite investors.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gasoline prices are rising. Sales of Detroit's carmakers suffer as Japanese brands carve out a growing share of the American market. One of the nation's largest automobile manufacturers flirts with bankruptcy. Sound familiar?

headline.main: If Detroit Calls, U.S. May Not Replay the Bailout Role

docs.snippet: The government shows no signs of hurrying to the auto industry's rescue and the reasons are telling.

docs.lead_paragraph: Retail sales increased a better-than-expected 0.6 percent in March, the Commerce Department reported Thursday. The gain came after shoppers took a breather in February and sales fell 0.8 percent, according to revised figures. In March, sales rose at auto dealers, furniture stores, building and garden centers, sporting goods, books and music stores, and health and beauty shops, among others. That offset weakness at electronics and appliances stores and a dip in sales at gasoline stations. Sales were flat at clothing stores and grocery stores.

headline.main: Retail Sales Rebounded in March, Rising 0.6%

docs.abstract: Commerce Department issues revised report that shows retail sales rose better-than-expected 0.6 percent in March; reports stockpiles of unsold goods were flat in February, suggesting businesses were trying to keep inventories fairly lean; University of Michigan reports consumer sentiment rose to 89.2 in April from 88.9 in March; Labor Department reports new filings for unemployment benefits rose by 12,000 last week, to 313,000; graphs (M)
docs.snippet: The gain came after shoppers took a breather in February and sales fell 0.8 percent, according to revised figures.

docs.lead_paragraph: Donald Navarro, 28, is a part-time chef at Bliss, a vegetarian restaurant in Brooklyn, and a full-time student at Queens College. He says Gov. George E. Pataki's tuition assistance cuts, announced Wednesday and among 202 vetoes to the state legislature's budget, will make it impossible for him to balance work and study. The changes in tuition assistance guidelines would require him to take 15 credits, instead of the current 12, each semester in order to qualify for full financial aid.. ''There's no way I can work and take 15 credits,'' said Mr. Navarro, a double major in political science and philosophy. Instead, he said, ''I'll be getting myself in a bigger debt hole, because I'm taking out federal loans and loans from my family.''

headline.main: As Budget Pain Filters Down, New Yorkers Start to Cry Out

docs.abstract: Impact of Gov George E Pataki's vetos and budget cuts begin to be felt across New York Sstate as students scramble to get tuition paid and health care industry tries to figure out how to take care of services for those cut from assistance programs; Senate majority leader Joseph L Bruno speaks out against cuts that Pataki holds are essential to maintaining financial stability in state; photo (M)
docs.snippet: College students, some of whom face a reduction in tuition assistance, are one group that would be affected by Gov. George E. Pataki's $2.9 billion cut to the Legislature's budget.
docs.section_name: Health; Education; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: General Motors expects to take a pretax charge of at least $1 billion in the first quarter related to its new retiree health care agreement, and the charge could increase to $3 billion as the automaker discusses the proper accounting treatment for it with regulators. In a regulatory filing Thursday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, G.M. said it would make three contributions of $1 billion each in 2006, 2007 and 2011 to a new plan. A court approved the agreement on March 31.

headline.main: G.M. Health Plan To Cut Earnings

docs.abstract: General Motors, in Securities and Exchange Commission filing, says it expects to take pretax charge of at least $1 billion in first quarter related to its new retiree health care agreement with United Auto Workers union; charge could rise to $3 billion as GM discusses proper accounting treatment with regulators (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Mitt Romney signed a bill to provide nearly universal health insurance, but vetoed a provision penalizing employers who do not provide coverage.

headline.main: Massachusetts Legislation on Insurance Becomes Law
headline.print_headline: Massachusetts Legislation On Insurance Becomes Law

docs.snippet: Gov. Mitt Romney signed a bill to provide nearly universal health insurance, but vetoed a provision penalizing employers who do not provide coverage.

byline.original: By PAM BELLUCK and KATIE ZEZIMA

docs.lead_paragraph: After five years of stock market gains, shares of health insurance companies have been on a slide so far this year, down 8.6 percent since Jan. 1, as measured by a Standard & Poor's index of health insurers. Analysts blame profit-taking by big investors who have sold their insurance stocks and transferred their bets to commodities and energy.

headline.main: Robust Health Insurers Suffer Infirmities in 2006

docs.snippet: After five years of stock market gains, shares of health insurance companies have been on a slide so far this year, down 8.6 percent since the start of the year.

docs.lead_paragraph: Charlie King, a Democratic candidate for attorney general of New York, began running his first television advertisement yesterday. The ad, a 30-second spot, is being shown on cable and network television in New York City, Syracuse, Rochester, Buffalo and Albany. Mr. King's campaign staff did not disclose how much is being spent for the commercials. PRODUCER -- Jay Rabinowitz, Surreal Communications. ON THE SCREEN -- The ad opens with Mr. King standing outdoors in a blazer and an open-collar shirt, with trees in the background. It then slowly zooms in on a black-and-white photograph of Mr. King at age 7, with his father, mother and younger brother. Mr. King then describes his concerns about the medical care provided to his father, who died of cancer in 1994. The ad continues with Mr. King in 2006, sitting and strolling while speaking with various people, in suburban-looking yards and on streets. It ends with Mr. King speaking into the camera. THE SCRIPT -- Mr. King narrates the ad, telling viewers: ''I'm Charlie King. I'm running for attorney general. And here's one reason why: My father was my hero. When he died from cancer, I wondered whether he received the best medical care possible. As attorney general, I'll fight to make sure medical decisions are made by you and your doctor, not by insurance companies that deny necessary treatment.'' The ad then returns to Mr. King among various New Yorkers as he says: ''You can help, too. Join my people's campaign and share with me your stories of insurance company abuse. Together we can make New York better.'' At that point, a man speaks in support of Mr. King, saying, ''We're with you, Charlie.'' At the conclusion, Mr. King looks into the camera and says, ''I'm Charlie King, running for attorney general.'' SCORECARD -- By emphasizing his family, specifically his father's death from cancer, Mr. King takes the safe route of focusing on medical care, an issue that his campaign staff suggests resonates with all New Yorkers. Mr. King's appeal to New York residents to call or write in with personal examples of health care claim denials are meant to tap into voter discontent over the health care system. In a six-candidate Democratic primary battle that has been dominated by Andrew M. Cuomo, the former housing secretary, and Mark Green, the former New York City public advocate, the King ads are intended to raise the candidate's visibility. Mr. King is hoping to heighten his recognition among the large number of voters undecided about the attorney general's race. JONATHAN P. HICKS
docs.abstract: Review of television advertisment for Charlie King, who seeks to be New York State Democratic candidate for Attorney General; photo (S)
